text: joining us now from our Washington
bureau is science reporter Sabrina
taverney see with the story of a
microbiologist with a mission to find
out whether drug-resistant germs are
making their way from farm animals into
people hi Sabrina hi David so I tell us
who is Lance price and how did you find
him so men's price is actually a
microbiologist who is a self-described
order of things who has a lot of things
in his freezer that he analyzes he had
originally started in research in in
anthrax for bio defense and was looking
at the ways that cipro is resisted by
various bio weapons but that he oh yes
psupero data is that powerful antibiotic
that they were using during the anthrax
attacks right that's right that's right
exactly so he decided that he wanted to
move into an area that was that had a
broader public health application and so
he was started looking at antibiotic
resistant germs in particular asking the
question what share of the germs that
are resistant to antibiotics start on
the farm in big industrial scale farms
in the United States so what is dr.
price doing what's his experiment so he
had his researchers go around to all the
major grocery stores in Flagstaff
Arizona for a whole year and I think
about twice a month purchase all of the
meat products and the major brands of
meat in the grocery stores and they made
samples of all of these of all of these
meat products and now they are analyzing
them and doing genomics sort of mapping
the full genetic sequence of all of
these different products and so the idea
is to match the full picture of the
organism's genes too and that they found
in the meat to to infections in people
and the infection that he's chosen is
the urinary tract infection because it's
very common for women about eight
million of them a year for American
women what's he finding out so we don't
really know yet his his results he has
early results that are due out in the
fall but he is finding a fairly high
instance of these germs in particularly
in turkey in the samples that they've
collected but so far we don't know yet
what share are connected to the
infections in women so this is something
that we will only learn later in the
fall well Sabrina taverney see
Washington science reporter for The New
York Times a lot of action on the food
safety front thanks for filling us in
thanks a lot
